user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UtTest_AddSubTest:
```c
void UtTest_AddSubTest(void (*Test)(void), void (*Setup)(void), void (*Teardown)(void), const char *GroupName,
                       const char *TestName)
{
    char        CompleteTestName[128];
    const char *GroupPtr;
    const char *TestPtr;

    /* Remove any common prefix between the two names.
     * They are often function names that all start with "Test_XXX"
     * and this repetitive information just becomes clutter.
     */
    GroupPtr = GroupName;
    TestPtr  = TestName;
    while (*GroupPtr != 0 && *GroupPtr == *TestPtr)
    {
        ++GroupPtr;
        ++TestPtr;
    }

    /*
     * Only break at an underscore(_) to avoid weird effects
     */
    while (TestPtr > TestName && *TestPtr != '_')
    {
        --TestPtr;
    }
    if (*TestPtr == '_')
    {
        ++TestPtr;
    }

    /*
     * Remove a remaining "Test_" prefix on the group name.
     * Again just to remove common repetitive content
     */
    GroupPtr = GroupName;
    if (strncmp(GroupPtr, "Test_", 5) == 0)
    {
        GroupPtr += 5;
    }

    (void)snprintf(CompleteTestName, sizeof(CompleteTestName), "%s.%s", GroupPtr, TestPtr);

    UtTest_AddCommon(Test, Setup, Teardown, CompleteTestName, UTASSERT_GROUP_TEST);
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
(void)snprintf(CompleteTestName, sizeof(CompleteTestName), "%s.%s", GroupPtr, TestPtr);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: Not violated. MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 specifically targets string-handling functions from <string.h> (memcpy, strcpy, strlen, etc.). The fragment uses snprintf (from <stdio.h>), so Rule 21.17 does not directly apply. In this code, GroupPtr and TestPtr are derived from the NUL-terminated inputs GroupName and TestName and are never advanced past their strings’ bounds, so snprintf("%s.%s", GroupPtr, TestPtr) will read only within those objects. A possible violation scenario would be if the caller passed non-NUL-terminated buffers or invalid pointers for GroupName/TestName; in that case snprintf could read beyond the objects’ bounds (but that is a caller contract issue, not a direct breach of Rule 21.17 by this call).
